facts.text: On April 10, 1953 the estate of the joint Hindu family of which the respondent was a member was partitioned.

anchor.surface_text: On April 10, 1953 the estate of the joint Hindu family of which the respondent was a member was partitioned, and the respondent was allotted, besides other properties, 400shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar

facts.text: Respondent was allotted 400 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd. on partition.

anchor.surface_text: partitioned, and the respondent was allotted, besides other properties, 400shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd., and was made liable to pay a business debt amounting to Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi.

facts.text: Respondent made liable to pay business debt of Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent was allotted, besides other properties, 400shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd., and was made liable to pay a business debt amounting to Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi.

facts.text: On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills.

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills which fell of to his share.

facts.text: Deed of trust settled 300 shares numbering 1 to 300 for benefit of creditors and other beneficiaries.

anchor.surface_text: AND WHEREAS for discharge of the debts detailed in the schedule appearing hereafter, the author number as absolute owner of the said shares has decided to settle on trust three hundred shares numbering 1 to 300 both inclusive, out of the said shares for the benefit of his creditors and other beneficiaries named hereafter and for the objects mentioned hereafter.

facts.text: Four persons including the respondent appointed as trustees, respondent as Chairman during lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: By el. 3 four persons including the respondent were appointed trustees, and the respondent was to hold the office of Chairman of the Trust during his lifetime.

facts.text: Shares to stand in name of Chairman who can vote and operate bank accounts.

anchor.surface_text: In the books of the Company, the shares will stand in the name of the Chairman for the time being, who will have the power to operate the Bank accounts of the Trust, to preside at the meetings, exercise the right of th e vote in respect of the shares of the Trust.

facts.text: Trustees entitled to mortgage or pledge shares to pay debts but not sell except after 10 years if needed.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees shall number be entitled to sell the shares except as provided hereafter but they can mortgage or pledge the same for raising funds as they may feel necessary for paying off the debts of the author, provided

facts.text: Debts in Schedule A to receive topmost priority, no spending till paid off, sell after 10 years if not paid from income.

anchor.surface_text: The payment of the debts of the author as detailed in Schedule A referred to above shall receive the topmost priority and the trustees shall number spend any money out of the trust property or its income in any direction till they have paid off all the debts of the author, provided always if the trustees are unable to pay off the debts, out of the income i.e. dividends, bonuses etc. of the shares within a period of ten years they shall be entitled to sell the same or part of it and thus pay off the debts that may be due at that time.

facts.text: Respondent claimed before Income-tax Officer that dividend on 300 shares is trust income, he divested ownership.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed before the Income-tax Officer, Eward. Amritsar that the dividend received by the trustees in respect of 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills was the income of the Trust and that he had numberconcern with that income as he had divested himself irrevocably of the ownership of the shares

facts.text: Respondent claimed deduction of Rs. 19,856/- as interest to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand.

anchor.surface_text: and that in any event Rs. 19,856/- being the amount due as interest to R. B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand should be allowed as a permissible deduction in companyputing the net income from dividend of the shares.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected claims, held trust fictitious.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytentions of the respondent, holding that the Trust was a fictitious transaction.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held no irrevocable transfer, s.16(1)(c) applies.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the respondent had number irrevocably transferred the 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills and therefore by virtue of s. 16 1  c  proviso one the respondent companyld number escape liability to pay tax on the dividend from the share.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld ITO/AAC decision.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. but without success.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court at Chandigarh at instance of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal drew up a statement of the case and referred the following questions to the High Court at Chandigarh Whether the dividend income of 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills, Private Ltd. transferred by the assessee to S. Raghbir Singh Trust was the income of the assessee liable to tax?

facts.text: High Court answered first question in negative: dividend not assessee's income.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question.

facts.text: High Court declined to answer second question on deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave. the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Genuineness of the trust is not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Genuineness of the trust is numberlonger  1  53 I.T.R. 195,202. in dispute.

facts.text: Direction for shares in Chairman's name due to s.33 Indian Companies Act 1913 preventing notice of trust on register.

anchor.surface_text: The direction that the shares are to stand in the name of the Chairman for the time being appears to have been necessitated by s. 33 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 which prevented numberice of any trust, expressed, implied or companystructive to be entered on the register.

facts.text: Trust deed expressly irrevocable.

anchor.surface_text: The deed is in terms expressly irrevocable, but on that account the operation of the first proviso is number excluded.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Income-tax Act enumerates the exemptions and exclusions admissible in the companyputation of total income in certain specified cases. The material part of cl.  c  of sub-s.  1  of s. 16 is as follows In companyputing the total income of the assessee--  c  all income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition whether revocable or number, and whether effected before or after the companymencement of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1939  VII of 1939 , from assets remaining the property of the settlor or disponer, shall be deemed to be income of the settlor or disponer, and all income arising to any person by virtue of a revocable transfer of assets shall be deemed to be income of the transferor Provided that for the purposes of this clause a settlement, disposition or transfer shall be deemed to be revocable if it companytains any provision for the retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or assets to the settlor, disponer or transferor, or in any way gives the settler, disponer or transferor a right to reassume power directly or indirectly over the income or assets Provided further that the expression settlement or disposition shall for the purposes of this clause include any disposition, trust, companyenant, agreement or arrangement, and the expression settlor or disponer in relation to a settlement or disposition shall include any person by whom the settlement or disposition was made Provided further that this clause shall number apply to any income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition which is number revocable for a period exceeding six years or during the lifetime of the person and from which income the settlor or disponer derives numberdirect or indirect benefit but that the settlor shall be liable to be assessed. on the said income as and when the power to revoke arises to him.

concepts.interpretation: Full text quoted and parsed; first proviso not attracted as no provision for retransfer or reassumption of power despite benefit to settlor via debt discharge.
concepts.unlisted_description: Clubs income from settlements/dispositions with settlor's income if revocable or assets not transferred.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that for the purposes of this clause a settlement, disposition or transfer shall be deemed to be revocable if it companytains any provision for the retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or assets to the settlor, disponer or transferor, or in any way gives the settler, disponer or transferor a right to reassume power directly or indirectly over the income or assets

concepts.interpretation: Requires explicit provision for retransfer or right to reassume power directly/indirectly; not attracted by mere indirect benefit like debt satisfaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income arises to trustees subject to trust obligations; direction to pay settlor's debts does not constitute retransfer or reassumption of power.

holdings.text: The settlor it is true obtains benefit from the trust consequent upon satisfaction of his liability, but on that account the first proviso is not attracted.

anchor.surface_text: The settlor it is true obtains benefit from the trust companysequent upon satisfaction of his liability, but on that account the first proviso is number attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indirect benefit to settlor via debt discharge insufficient to trigger proviso without specific provision.

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the argument of counsel for the revenue that by the use of the expression indirectly in the first proviso the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of cl. c cases where the settler was under the guise of a trust seeking to discharge his own liability.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of companynsel for the revenue that by the use of the expression indirectly in the first proviso the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of el. c cases where the settler was under the guise of a trust seeking to discharge his own liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects purposive expansion; 'indirectly' limited to provisions for retransfer or power reassumption.

holdings.text: The proviso contemplates cases in which there is a provision for retransfer of the income or assets and such provision is for retransfer directly or indirectly. It also contemplates cases where there is a provision which confers a right upon the settlor to reassume power over the income or assets directly or indirectly. It is the provision for retransfer directly or indirectly of income or assets or for reassumption of power directly or indirectly over income or assets which brings the case within the first proviso.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso companytemplates cases in which there is a provision for retransfer of the income or assets and such provision is for retransfer directly or indirectly. It also companytemplates cases where there is a provision which companyfers a right upon the settlor to reassume power over the income or assets directly or indirectly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of first proviso requires specific type of provision; no broader scope.

holdings.text: Cases in which there is a settlement, but there is no provision in the settlement for retransfer or right to reassume power do not fall within the proviso, even if as a result of the settlement, the settler obtains a benefit.

anchor.surface_text: Cases in which there is a settlement, but there is numberprovision in the settlement for retransfer or right to reassume power do number fail within the proviso, even if as a result of the settlement, the settler obtains a benefit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of specified provision excludes application regardless of settlor benefit.

holdings.text: It has been held in two cases decided by the High Court of Bombay that a person under an obligation arising out of his status may execute a trust to discharge his own obligation without attracting the operation of s. 16(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It has been held in two cases decided by the High Court of Bombay that a person under an obligation arising out of his status may execute a trust to discharge his own obligation without attracting the operation of s. 15 1  c . In Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1  under a companysent decree.

The proviso contemplates cases in which there is a provision for retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or assets to the settlor, or where it gives to the settlor a right to reassume power directly or indirectly over the income or assets.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of counsel for the revenue that by the use of the expression indirectly in the first proviso the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of el. c cases where the settler was under the guise of a trust seeking to discharge his own liability. The proviso contemplates cases in which there is a provision for retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or assets to the settlor, or where it gives to the settlor a right to reassume power directly or indirectly over the income or assets.
